Santana
I am informed that Santana is a most parsimonious and miserly, amassing money & lands at a most extraordinary rate, he is not a young man - his riches may [?] in sustaining him in tottering power - His Wife is described as a most slatternly woman, & generally found  'in Mexican deshabille' - A pretty pair!  On one occasion he invited some fellows to dine with him, but requested them to bring their own wine! for he thought strong liquors very bad - What a catch for Father Matthew & his followers.  The blood-thirsty, treaty-breaking, [?] Santana!

  His enemies are many, but some how or other he keeps them quiet, but armed forces who obey him, creatures who can only rise and keep commands, by acceedy to his measures - On the occasion, he sent for Arita who was in command of the Texan frontier watching until a friendly eye the movements of the Traitor Gen

S.   Santana's life has been often attempted, and many ingenious plans have been resorted to.  Once a rich Musical gold snuff-box with precious stones, in which was secreted a small pistol & so arranged that in winding it up to a certain pitch, the pistol would off.  Santana suspecting that all was right, turned it about, the result being that the conspirator got himself shot dead - With regard to the ignorance even of Mexican Generals - [?Mr T?] when prisoner 1842 at Monterey, was treated kindly by Gl Reyes, & who questioned him about the Texan Army &c -
How many troops can you call into the field in a month?  20,000.  How do your make that out?  I calculate it from the number of Votes polled, & a number of boys who can handle the Rifle well - Where are your troops stationed?  In their own Lands on their own plantations.  How are they to be armed & clothed & provisioned?  Each Citizen soldier, funds himself & each has a good horse, & a good horn of powder & 50 bullets

Texas a young & gallant republic.  A few years since, but an obscure territory of Mexico - a Wilderness.

   The course of Texas is a romance in history - a strange problem in political philosophy - an act in the great drama of demography
   Her population are adventurous Emigrants from the United States & Europe, who went there, conquered a great extent of country, organized themselves in a republic, & have maintained themselves by their valor industry & wisdom.
  This had been recognized by the U. States, England, France, Belgium & the Hanseatic States [?] have treaties with her.
  In a few years Texas will have a great influence on Mexico {?] & may absorb many of her poor [?]
  Let old Europe look & wonder at the progress of self-government & civilization in the New World.

Expedition in Steamer Lafitte  Original notes
Journied on P. steamer Lafitte John Wade Commander - March 14, 1842. Monday.  After a few days - the Inhabitnats have promised a [?] for [?] here - [?] have took the [?] Volunteers they are - In the afternoon left Galveston - Mr Santa Ana & [?] Wilkinson.
March 15 Tuesday - During the night N.N. & [?Keip...?] about 6 sailors  Jim Shane got down [?] and made at [?Cabatto?] - the Bar pretty fair No one that came without pilot -
Wednesday 16th  [?] on those exercising - vague rumors only & the Mexicans [?Ex.....?] at [?] - [?] & infantry invade - appoint Sargeant of [?] division - Went on then to café with Baron [?] & lady - they know not what to do - & they will not be able to do much apparently
Thursday 17  At day brake got under waigh so for miles it of Esperita Santa Inlet - beat to quarter for a sail to Leeward - boarded her - a try only from Mobile and [?][?]  When off E.L. lnlet saw a Sloop ashore under suspicious circumstances - [?] down to her manned by [?] away they went - they got into the breakers - 2 apart - for some moments we thought we had let some of our help - but they soon got a ashore - The Washington came up with us - we then them dry cloths for the [?] & we then bore off for San [?] crew beseech us tomorrow in Aransas Bay - Got over Aransas bar very well - I came to senator for the night
Friday 18th Daylight got under weigh - fell in with the Santana and our Gig - 10 am came to [?] Live Oak pc this is a pretty country - & in the vicinity are some fine Indians (Corrujuas San Kansas) they are friendly were driven out of the State X had the reputation of being Canibals
[at bottom of page]
All those [?] have plenty fine fish

Saturday 19th  Cloudy weather all gone - fine & clear with beautiful breezes - What want the [?] with you for such a climate - 2 PM Came too off Copans.  Capt Wade went ashore - all the [?] gone only a few laders left - they inform us that is [?] reported that 300 of our men had gone thro the [?] (Refuges) a few days since on their way South - 5 PM Made for Black [?] the [?] part of [?] Bay to take on wood - Shoals & sand Banks - but with care there is no danger - keep this land on port going - we draw 5 fts and get along famously - Tide appears to run strong - bark comes to anchor after piloting for a passage in Copans Bay 6 fts.
Sunday 20 - No 1 got made [?] made Block Pt. in an hour - [?] leaving coast - only one family came [?] Sent an Express off to Inform (Refuges) about 15 miles -  from this place we expect to have news [?] of our own party - Left too Wooding - [?] went at it - he loaded it all day - Wood.  The Margaret rather sweet   Lots from strong firewood - The Margaret is of the [?] [?]  -Emandgottn flor & Margaret goes fine for [?]  The huge seaspray now the [?] was laden with the [?] perfumes of the flowers - Had a shoot in the afternoon - Saw plenty rabbits - Deer abounding themselves - No sound of the army our cording party has scared them - This must be a fine country for game & fish.  The Shores of this Bay much in line be [?] and habitatus - [?] cities to conduct the Game and[?] with the intention & with exporting of its produce.  The Poultry on Shore are large - Mr. Brathoy complains of a partial drought for the last 11 months - Saw some [?] (ivopal)
Monday 21st   Wooding all day - Express returned - brought us no more news than we had before - On the 7th a party of Mexicans came on at Sn Patrius & killed Messrs Carnes, Snodgrass Wells & Willis & some 4 Lipan Indians - the following day they came own - some 40 of them to Corpus Christe distributed [?] proclamation & started off towards the Rio Grand - Why was not something done at Corpus Christe to revenge the deaths of Carnes & hi friends?!
Tuesday 22nd  8 am got under weigh for Live Oak Pt around noon - got some water - we got the wells dry - [?] Changed [five unclear words]

It would appear that the powerful force of the Mexican marching army is at Montery about 10 000 strong - Al Moncton says [?] 3000 - From these places Arista sent his proclamation into [?] of which no one could believe a word/ with some 6 to 700 men and those disarmed - to Spy into our readiness for War - According to their reports & our belligerent Manifestations Arista will not - He may march with his whole force - & if he does those that we have already in the field will thrash him - We may lose some few but the Victory will be ours [?] up & doing - by land & sea & all that can result in my poor opinion is to keep us a hot [?] & their finest the getting in at the [?] - some of them we have already - Our fleet under Commodore [?] is to the South - We are watching the coast with our Small but very efective [sic] squadrons.  Our land forces & volunteers muster pretty strong along the San Antonio & [?] of that [?] - and doubtless our friends on the Mississippi are forming in to operations - and it [?] not be a matter of astonishment if one fine morning the Texas Flag [?shows up here?] floating over Monterey - & what may follow if a muster strong enough may surprise the west [?] of Santana himself
Wednesday 23rd  Accompd Capt Wade & others in 'Washington' to Corpus Christi - had to beat down - [?] land for S.E. arrived at 3.30 PM - High bluff land - Saw [?] Kenney & Aubrey - & the rest of the inhabitants - (? Holmes & Hopkins?) Carver & his party, had been for some time acting as a Guard to this place - they had gone out against the wish of the people here - & were found by a party of Mexicans under [?] asleep in the Middle of the day & Killed them - Cameron only escaping - [?] having an old spite against [?] [?] has gone off to the Army & will make his report - [?] effects abou 18 inches C. Cristi 2 papers the N the one short & narrow 4 ½ to 5 ft there is no water in it.  Aransas 8 to 10 ft - Anibaje at [?] full We made that out to chance away & then C. Christi to Bay could be rendered navigable
